title: Formwork Design for Concrete Wall
problem: Design the spacing of studs for a 12-ft tall concrete wall form. The form sheathing is 3/4-inch plywood (bending strength $F_b = 1,930$ psi, rolling shear $F_s = 72$ psi). The concrete will be placed at a rate of 7 ft/hr with internal vibration. Use Type I cement at 70°F. Calculate the maximum stud spacing based on bending and shear in the plywood sheathing.
required: Calculate the maximum allowable stud spacing based on sheathing capacity.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Lateral Pressure on Formwork
solution_steps.content:
Using ACI 347-14 Equation (4.1) for walls with $R < 7$ ft/hr (or with vibration):

$$p_{max} = C_w C_c \left(150 + \frac{9,000R}{T + 50}\right)$$

Where:
- $C_w = 1.0$ (unit weight coefficient for normal weight concrete)
- $C_c = 1.0$ (chemistry coefficient for Type I cement)
- $R = 7$ ft/hr (rate of placement)
- $T = 70$°F (temperature)

$$p_{max} = 1.0 \times 1.0 \times \left(150 + \frac{9,000 \times 7}{70 + 50}\right)$$

$$p_{max} = 150 + \frac{63,000}{120} = 150 + 525 = 675 \text{ psf}$$

**Maximum pressure limit:**
$$p_{max} = p_{min}(150h, 2,000 \text{ psf})$$

For 12 ft wall: $150 \times 12 = 1,800$ psf > 675 psf

**Design pressure = 675 psf**

solution_steps.title: Determine Plywood Section Properties
solution_steps.content:
For 3/4-inch plywood (using typical values for B-B Class I plywood):

- Thickness $t = 0.75$ in
- Section modulus (for stress parallel to face grain):
$$S = 0.455 \text{ in}^3/\text{ft}$$
- Moment of inertia:
$$I = 0.199 \text{ in}^4/\text{ft}$$
- Rolling shear constant:
$$Ib/Q = 7.187 \text{ in}^2/\text{ft}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Maximum Span Based on Bending
solution_steps.content:
Plywood acts as a continuous beam over multiple supports. Using the 3-span condition:

$$M_{max} = \frac{wl^2}{10}$$

For bending stress:
$$f_b = \frac{M}{S} \leq F_b$$

$$\frac{wl^2}{10S} \leq F_b$$

Solving for span $l$:
$$l = \sqrt{\frac{F_b \times 10S}{w}}$$

Where $w = 675/12 = 56.25$ lb/in (uniform load per inch width):

$$l = \sqrt{\frac{1,930 \times 10 \times 0.455}{56.25}}$$

$$l = \sqrt{156.2} = 12.5 \text{ in}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Maximum Span Based on Rolling Shear
solution_steps.content:
For rolling shear in plywood:

$$f_s = \frac{V}{Ib/Q} \leq F_s$$

For 3-span condition:
$$V = 0.6wl$$

$$\frac{0.6wl}{Ib/Q} \leq F_s$$

Solving for span $l$:
$$l = \frac{F_s \times Ib/Q}{0.6w}$$

$$l = \frac{72 \times 7.187}{0.6 \times 56.25}$$

$$l = \frac{517.5}{33.75} = 15.3 \text{ in}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Governing Spacing
solution_steps.content:
**Summary of maximum spans:**
- Based on bending: 12.5 in
- Based on rolling shear: 15.3 in

**Bending governs.**

Practical stud spacing: Use **12 inches on center** (standard increment below 12.5 in)

final_answer: The maximum stud spacing is **12 inches on center**, governed by bending in the plywood sheathing. This provides adequate capacity for the 675 psf design pressure with a 12-inch stud spacing.

title: Flagpole Foundation Design
problem: Design the foundation depth for a 50-ft tall flagpole with a 12-inch diameter at the base, tapering to 6 inches at the top. The flagpole is made of aluminum with a total weight of 1,200 lb. The design wind speed is 110 mph (Risk Category II, Exposure C). The flag is 8 ft × 12 ft. The foundation is a cylindrical concrete pier with a 3-ft diameter in soil with a unit weight of 120 pcf. Determine the required embedment depth.
given: Base diameter = 12 in, top diameter = 6 in
required: Calculate the required foundation embedment depth for stability.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Wind Force on Flagpole
solution_steps.content:
Using ASCE 7-16 Chapter 29 for other structures.

**Velocity pressure:**
$$q_z = 0.00256 K_z K_{zt} K_d V^2$$

At top of flagpole ($z = 50$ ft), Exposure C:
$K_z = 1.09$, $K_d = 0.95$

$$q_z = 0.00256 \times 1.09 \times 1.0 \times 0.95 \times (110)^2$$
$$q_z = 0.00265 \times 12,100 = 32.1 \text{ psf}$$

**Effective projected area of flagpole:**
$$A_{ep} = \text{Average diameter} \times H \times G \times C_f$$

Average diameter = $(12 + 6)/2 = 9$ in = 0.75 ft
$G = 0.85$, $C_f = 0.7$ (cylinder)

$$A_{ep} = 0.75 \times 50 \times 0.85 \times 0.7 = 22.3 \text{ ft}^2$$

**Force on pole:**
$$F_{pole} = q_z \times A_{ep} = 32.1 \times 22.3 = 716 \text{ lb}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Wind Force on Flag
solution_steps.content:
**Force on flag:**
$$A_{flag} = 8 \times 12 = 96 \text{ ft}^2$$

Using $G = 1.0$ and $C_f = 1.4$ for flag:
$$F_{flag} = q_z \times A_{flag} \times G \times C_f$$
$$F_{flag} = 32.1 \times 96 \times 1.0 \times 1.4 = 4,314 \text{ lb}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Total Overturning Moment
solution_steps.content:
**Moment from pole force:**
Force acts at centroid = $H/2 = 25$ ft above base
$$M_{pole} = 716 \times 25 = 17,900 \text{ lb-ft}$$

**Moment from flag force:**
Flag at top, force acts at 50 ft above base
$$M_{flag} = 4,314 \times 50 = 215,700 \text{ lb-ft}$$

**Total overturning moment:**
$$M_{total} = 17,900 + 215,700 = 233,600 \text{ lb-ft}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Required Embedment Depth
solution_steps.content:
For a cylindrical pier with lateral load, using the Brinch Hansen method:

The ultimate lateral capacity of a drilled shaft:
$$H_u = \frac{M_u}{D + L_f}$$

Where $D$ is the diameter and $L_f$ is the load eccentricity.

For a simplified approach, using passive pressure:

**Passive pressure on front of pier:**
$$P_p = \frac{1}{2} K_p \gamma D^2$$

For a factor of safety of 2.0:

Taking moments about the base:
$$M_R = P_p \times \frac{D}{3} = \frac{1}{2} K_p \gamma D^3 \times \frac{1}{3} = \frac{K_p \gamma D^3}{6}$$

For $K_p \approx 3.0$ (loose sand):
$$M_R = \frac{3.0 \times 120 \times D^3}{6} = 60D^3$$

For stability:
$$\frac{M_R}{M_O} \geq 2.0$$

$$\frac{60D^3}{233,600} \geq 2.0$$

$$D^3 \geq 7,787$$
$$D \geq 19.8 \text{ ft}$$

solution_steps.title: Include Weight of Foundation
solution_steps.content:
With concrete pier weight included:
$$W_{conc} = \pi \times (1.5)^2 \times D \times 150 = 1,060D \text{ lb}$$

Resisting moment from weight:
$$M_W = W_{total} \times \frac{D}{2}$$

This reduces required depth slightly. Using **D = 18 ft** with weight contribution provides adequate safety.

final_answer: The required foundation embedment depth is **$D = 18$ ft** for a 3-ft diameter concrete pier. This provides adequate resistance against the 233,600 lb-ft overturning moment from wind loads on the flagpole and flag.

title: Scaffolding Load Capacity
problem: A tube-and-coupler scaffold system is being designed for a masonry restoration project. The scaffold is 6 ft wide and will support workers, materials, and a masonry wall section. The maximum anticipated load is 3 workers (250 lb each with tools), 2,000 lb of masonry materials, and a distributed load from the masonry wall of 50 psf over a 6 ft × 30 ft area. Determine if the scaffold legs rated at 4,000 lb each are adequate. The scaffold has 4 legs.
given: Wall load: 50 psf over 6 ft × 30 ft area
required: Check if the scaffold leg capacity is adequate for the anticipated loads.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Total Applied Load
solution_steps.content:
**Worker load:**
$$W_{workers} = 3 \times 250 = 750 \text{ lb}$$

**Material load:**
$$W_{materials} = 2,000 \text{ lb}$$

**Wall load:**
$$W_{wall} = 50 \text{ psf} \times 6 \text{ ft} \times 30 \text{ ft} = 9,000 \text{ lb}$$

**Total load:**
$$W_{total} = 750 + 2,000 + 9,000 = 11,750 \text{ lb}$$

solution_steps.title: Distribute Load to Scaffold Legs
solution_steps.content:
For a uniformly loaded scaffold with 4 legs:

**Load per leg (assuming uniform distribution):**
$$P_{leg} = \frac{W_{total}}{4} = \frac{11,750}{4} = 2,938 \text{ lb}$$

However, the wall load may not be uniformly distributed. For conservative design, assume 60% of wall load goes to the two legs nearest the wall:

**Wall load to front legs:**
$$W_{front} = 0.6 \times 9,000 = 5,400 \text{ lb per side}$$
$$P_{front} = \frac{5,400}{2} = 2,700 \text{ lb per front leg}$$

**Remaining load to rear legs:**
$$W_{rear} = 750 + 2,000 + 3,600 = 6,350 \text{ lb}$$
$$P_{rear} = \frac{6,350}{2} = 3,175 \text{ lb per rear leg}$$

solution_steps.title: Apply Load Combinations
solution_steps.content:
Per OSHA 1926.451, scaffolds shall be capable of supporting at least 4 times the maximum intended load.

**Maximum intended load:**
$$P_{max} = \max(2,700, 3,175) = 3,175 \text{ lb}$$

**Required capacity:**
$$P_{required} = 4 \times P_{max} = 4 \times 3,175 = 12,700 \text{ lb}$$

This would require 4 legs each capable of 12,700 lb.

**Alternative check:** Per ASCE 37-14 for construction loads:
$$P_u = 1.4D + 1.7L$$

Where D includes material storage and L includes workers:
$$P_u = 1.4(2,000 + 9,000)/4 + 1.7(750)/4$$
$$P_u = 1.4(2,750) + 1.7(188) = 3,850 + 319 = 4,169 \\text{ lb per leg}$$

solution_steps.title: Check Capacity
solution_steps.content:
**OSHA check:**
Required capacity = 12,700 lb > 4,000 lb (available)
**FAILS by OSHA criteria**

**ASCE 37 check:**
Required capacity = 4,169 lb > 4,000 lb (available)
**FAILS**

The scaffold legs are **NOT adequate** for the specified loads.

solution_steps.title: Recommend Solution
solution_steps.content:
Options to address the capacity issue:

1. **Add more legs:** Use additional intermediate supports
2. **Reduce load limits:** Limit material storage to 1,500 lb
3. **Use heavier-duty scaffold:** Select legs with 5,000+ lb capacity
4. **Reduce wall load area:** Stage wall work in smaller sections

**Recommended:** Use scaffold legs with minimum 5,000 lb capacity each, or add intermediate supports.

final_answer: The scaffold legs are **NOT adequate**. The required capacity is 4,169 lb per leg (ASCE 37) or 12,700 lb per leg (OSHA 4× rule), but each leg is only rated for 4,000 lb. Recommendations: use higher-capacity legs (5,000+ lb) or add intermediate supports.

title: Crane Lift Planning
problem: A mobile crane with a 100-ton capacity is being used to lift a precast concrete beam. The crane will operate at a 30-ft radius with a 60-ft boom length. From the crane load chart, the capacity at this configuration is 18,000 lb. The beam weighs 12,000 lb, the rigging weighs 500 lb, and the load block weighs 800 lb. Calculate the load percentage and determine if the lift is within the crane's rated capacity. The crane is set up on firm, level ground with outriggers fully extended.
required: Calculate the load percentage and determine if the lift is permissible.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Total Lifted Load
solution_steps.content:
Per OSHA 1926.1417, the total load includes:

**Total lifted load:**
$$W_{total} = W_{beam} + W_{rigging} + W_{block}$$
$$W_{total} = 12,000 + 500 + 800 = 13,300 \text{ lb}$$

solution_steps.title: Compare to Rated Capacity
solution_steps.content:
**Rated capacity at 30-ft radius, 60-ft boom:**
$$C_{rated} = 18,000 \text{ lb}$$

**Check if within capacity:**
$$W_{total} = 13,300 \text{ lb} < 18,000 \text{ lb}$$ ✓

The lift is within the rated capacity.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Load Percentage
solution_steps.content:
**Load percentage:**
$$\% Load = \frac{W_{total}}{C_{rated}} \times 100$$

$$\% Load = \frac{13,300}{18,000} \times 100 = 73.9\%$$

solution_steps.title: Check OSHA Requirements
solution_steps.content:
Per OSHA 1926.1417:

1. **The total load shall not exceed the rated capacity** - ✓ Satisfied ($13,300 < 18,000$ lb)

2. **When operating at 75% or more of capacity:**
   - Must not travel with load
   - Tag lines required
   - Lift director must be present

Since $73.9\% < 75\%$, the additional requirements for heavy lifts do not apply.

3. **Outriggers fully extended** - ✓ Satisfied

4. **Level ground** - ✓ Satisfied

solution_steps.title: Verify Wind Conditions
solution_steps.content:
OSHA requires that wind speed be considered. For this lift:

- Maximum wind speed for crane operations is typically 20-30 mph for standard lifts
- If wind exceeds 30 mph, additional precautions are required
- At wind speeds above 40 mph, operations should cease

The lift is **permissible** under normal conditions with wind speed below 30 mph.

final_answer: The lift is **permissible** with a load percentage of **73.9%** of rated capacity. The total lifted load (13,300 lb) is within the crane's rated capacity (18,000 lb). No additional heavy-lift requirements apply since the load is below 75% of capacity.

title: Temporary Bracing of Steel Column
problem: A W12×65 steel column (A992 steel) is being erected and requires temporary bracing until the permanent structure is connected. The column is 24 ft tall and weighs 65 lb/ft. The design wind pressure on the column face is 25 psf. Determine the required capacity of a single diagonal brace attached at the top of the column and at 15 ft from the base on an adjacent structure. Use a factor of safety of 1.5 for temporary bracing.
given: Wind pressure: 25 psf on column face
Brace attached at top (24 ft) to anchor at 15 ft height
required: Calculate the required brace capacity including the safety factor.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Wind Force on Column
solution_steps.content:
The W12×65 has a flange width of approximately 12 inches = 1 ft.

**Wind force on column:**
$$F_{wind} = p \times A = 25 \text{ psf} \times 1 \text{ ft} \times 24 \text{ ft} = 600 \text{ lb}$$

**Force acts at mid-height:**
$$y = 12 \text{ ft above base}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Overturning Moment
solution_steps.content:
**Moment from wind:**
$$M_w = F_{wind} \times \frac{H}{2} = 600 \times 12 = 7,200 \text{ lb-ft}$$

**This moment is resisted by the brace force.**

solution_steps.title: Determine Required Brace Force
solution_steps.content:
The brace resists overturning by providing a horizontal component.

**Geometry:**
- Brace attachment at column: 24 ft height
- Brace anchor: 15 ft height on adjacent structure
- Assume horizontal distance from column: 10 ft

**Brace angle:**
$$\theta = \arctan\left(\frac{24-15}{10}\right) = \arctan(0.9) = 42°$$

**Brace length:**
$$L = \sqrt{9^2 + 10^2} = \sqrt{181} = 13.5 \text{ ft}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Required Horizontal Brace Force
solution_steps.content:
Taking moments about the base of the column:

$$M_w = F_h \times 24$$

Where $F_h$ is the horizontal component of brace force.

$$F_h = \frac{M_w}{24} = \frac{7,200}{24} = 300 \text{ lb}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Brace Tension with Safety Factor
solution_steps.content:
**Brace tension (without FS):**
$$T = \frac{F_h}{\cos\theta} = \frac{300}{\cos(42°)} = \frac{300}{0.743} = 404 \text{ lb}$$

**With factor of safety:**
$$T_{design} = T \times FS = 404 \times 1.5 = 606 \text{ lb}$$

**Required brace capacity:** Use minimum 1,000 lb capacity brace for practical reasons.

Also check column weight contribution to stability:
$$W_{col} = 65 \times 24 = 1,560 \text{ lb}$$

This provides stabilizing moment that reduces brace requirements, but is typically ignored for temporary bracing design to be conservative.

final_answer: The required brace capacity is **606 lb** (with FS = 1.5). In practice, use a brace rated for at least **1,000 lb** capacity to provide additional safety margin for erection loads and dynamic effects.

title: Flagpole Foundation Depth for Overturning
problem: A temporary 50-ft tall steel flagpole is to be erected for a grand opening ceremony. The flagpole has a uniform diameter of 6 inches and will be embedded in a concrete foundation as a vertical cantilever. The total weight of the flagpole and its attached flag is 400 lbs. The site is located in Exposure C, and the basic wind speed is 105 mph (Risk Category I). Using the simplified method for solid freestanding towers and flagpoles (ASCE 7-16 Section 29.4), determine the required minimum depth of embedment for the foundation to resist overturning. Assume the soil is a dense gravel with an allowable lateral bearing pressure of 300 psf per foot of depth below grade (IBC Table 1806.2). Ignore passive pressure from the soil above the footing. The foundation is a 3-ft diameter concrete pier.
given: Allowable lateral soil bearing, $S = 300$ psf per ft of depth
required: Calculate the minimum required embedment depth ($d_e$) for the flagpole foundation.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Design Wind Force on Flagpole
solution_steps.content:
ASCE 7-16 Section 29.4.2 provides a simplified method for solid freestanding towers. The force is calculated using:
$$F = q_z \times G \times C_f \times A_f$$

First, calculate velocity pressure at the top of the pole ($z = 50$ ft). For Exposure C, from Table 26.10-1, $K_z$ at 50 ft = 1.09.
$K_d = 0.95$ (from Table 26.6-1 for Chimneys, Tanks, etc.), $K_{zt}=1.0$, $K_e=1.0$.
$$q_z = 0.00256 \times K_z \times K_{zt} \times K_d \times K_e \times V^2$$
$$q_z = 0.00256 \times 1.09 \times 1.0 \times 0.95 \times 1.0 \times (105)^2$$
$$q_z = 0.00256 \times 1.09 \times 0.95 \times 11,025$$
$$q_z = 29.17 \text{ psf}$$

Gust effect factor $G = 0.85$ for rigid structures.
Force coefficient $C_f = 0.7$ for round cross-sections per Section 29.4.2.
Projected area $A_f = h \times d = 50 \text{ ft} \times 0.5 \text{ ft} = 25 \text{ ft}^2$.

$$F = 29.17 \times 0.85 \times 0.7 \times 25 = 434 \text{ lbs}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Overturning Moment
solution_steps.content:
The wind load is assumed to act at the centroid of the projected area, which is at the mid-height of the pole ($h/2 = 25$ ft).

$$M_{OT} = F \times \frac{h}{2} = 434 \text{ lbs} \times 25 \text{ ft}$$
$$M_{OT} = 10,850 \text{ ft-lbs}$$

solution_steps.title: Apply IBC Embedment Method
solution_steps.content:
IBC 1807.3.2 allows an equivalent lateral bearing pressure method for poles embedded in soil. For a rigid pole (non-yielding), the required depth $d_e$ can be found by equating the applied moment to the resisting moment from the soil's lateral bearing. For a pier of diameter $D_f$, the total resisting force is approximated by a parabolic pressure distribution. The required depth can be solved using:

$$d_e^3 = \frac{2.34 \times M_{OT}}{S \times D_f}$$

This equation is derived from static equilibrium for a rigid vertical pile in a cohesive soil with increasing lateral resistance. $S$ is the allowable lateral bearing pressure in psf per foot of depth, and $D_f$ is the foundation diameter. (This is a common simplification found in geotechnical references and practice problems.)

Substitute values:
$$d_e^3 = \frac{2.34 \times 10,850 \text{ ft-lbs}}{300 \text{ psf/ft} \times 3.0 \text{ ft}}$$
$$d_e^3 = \frac{25,389}{900} = 28.21 \text{ ft}^3$$

$$d_e = \sqrt[3]{28.21} = 3.04 \text{ ft}$$

solution_steps.title: Check Minimum Depth Requirement
solution_steps.content: IBC 1807.3.2 also requires that the embedment depth be at least 4 ft 6 inches for poles supporting signs and fences, but for a temporary flagpole of this size, the calculated value governs. The total required foundation depth would be $d_e = 3.04$ ft, which is less than the height of the pier. Use $d_e = 3.1$ ft for design.

final_answer: The minimum required embedment depth is $3.1$ ft (37 inches).

title: Shoring System for Excavation Bracing
problem: A contractor is designing a timber shoring system for a 12-ft deep excavation in Type B soil. The excavation width is 10 ft. The shoring consists of vertical sheeting (wood planks) supported by horizontal wales at the top and bottom of the excavation, with cross-trench struts (braces) at each wale level. The struts are spaced at 6 ft horizontally along the trench. The soil unit weight is 120 pcf, and the equivalent fluid pressure for design of temporary shoring in Type B soil is 45 pcf (as permitted by OSHA Appendix C). Determine the axial load in each strut at the bottom wale level. Assume the wales are simply supported between struts and distribute the soil pressure to the struts as a uniform load over the tributary area.
given: Two levels of bracing: top at 2 ft below grade, bottom at 10 ft below grade
Equivalent fluid pressure for design, $p_{eq} = 45$ pcf (psf per ft of depth)
Soil unit weight given for context only (45 pcf is the apparent pressure for design)
required: Calculate the axial compressive load in each bottom strut (in kips).

solution_steps.title: Determine Pressure Diagram and Strut Loads
solution_steps.content:
OSHA Appendix C allows a simplified pressure diagram for braced excavations in Type B soil: a rectangular pressure distribution with pressure $p = p_{eq} \times H$ for the full height of the excavation, where $p_{eq} = 45$ pcf.

$$p_{max} = p_{eq} \times H = 45 \text{ pcf} \times 12 \text{ ft} = 540 \text{ psf}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Tributary Load on Bottom Wales
solution_steps.content:
The bottom wale is located at depth 10 ft. For a two-level bracing system with uniform pressure, the tributary area for the bottom wale is typically taken as the pressure acting on half the distance to the top wale and half the distance to the bottom of excavation.

Distance from top wale (2 ft) to bottom wale (10 ft) = 8 ft.
Half of this distance = 4 ft above the bottom wale.

Distance from bottom wale (10 ft) to bottom of excavation (12 ft) = 2 ft.
Half of this distance = 1 ft below the bottom wale.

**Total tributary height for bottom wale:** $h_{trib} = 4 + 1 = 5$ ft.

**Load per linear foot on bottom wale:**
$$w_{wale} = p_{max} \times h_{trib} = 540 \text{ psf} \times 5 \text{ ft} = 2,700 \text{ lb/ft}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Strut Load from Wale Reaction
solution_steps.content:
The bottom wale is a continuous beam supported by struts at 6 ft spacing. A conservative approach is to assume the wale is simply supported between struts, and each strut takes the reaction from half the span on either side.

**Tributary width for one strut:** $S_s = 6$ ft.

**Total load on one strut from the bottom wale:**
$$P_{strut} = w_{wale} \times S_s = 2,700 \text{ lb/ft} \times 6 \text{ ft}$$
$$P_{strut} = 16,200 \text{ lbs} = 16.2 \text{ kips}$$

solution_steps.title: Check Load Distribution Assumptions
solution_steps.content:
This calculation assumes the entire pressure load is resisted by the wales and struts, with no arching or soil cohesion reducing loads (conservative). The axial load in the strut is 16.2 kips compression.

**Note:** In a more detailed analysis, the pressure diagram might be trapezoidal, and the wales analyzed as continuous beams with settlements. However, for OSHA compliance and preliminary design, this simplified tributary area method is acceptable.

final_answer: The axial load in each bottom strut is $16.2$ kips (compression).

title: Temporary Crane Foundation Pad Bearing Pressure
codeSection: IBC 2018 Section 1806 (Allowable Load-Bearing Values of Soils)
problem: A 200-ton mobile crane will be used for steel erection. During a critical lift, the crane will operate with outriggers fully extended. The maximum outrigger reaction during the lift is estimated to be 350 kips. The crane mats (spreader pads) placed under each outrigger are 8 ft × 8 ft in plan. The soil at the site is a medium dense sand with an allowable bearing capacity of 6,000 psf for temporary construction loads. Check if the bearing pressure under the outrigger pad is within the allowable limit. If not, recommend a new pad size. Also, check the sliding stability of the pad if the horizontal shear force at the outrigger is 40 kips and the coefficient of friction between the pad and soil is 0.5.
required: Check if bearing pressure is within allowable limit.
If not, recommend a new square pad size.
Check factor of safety against sliding.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Actual Bearing Pressure
solution_steps.content:
The bearing pressure under the pad is:
$$q = \frac{P}{A} = \frac{350,000 \text{ lbs}}{64 \text{ ft}^2}$$
$$q = 5,468.75 \text{ psf} \approx 5,470 \text{ psf}$$

solution_steps.title: Compare with Allowable Bearing Pressure
solution_steps.content:
$q_{all} = 6,000$ psf
$q_{actual} = 5,470$ psf

$$5,470 \text{ psf} < 6,000 \text{ psf}$$

The bearing pressure is less than the allowable limit. The 8 ft × 8 ft pad is adequate for bearing.

solution_steps.title: Check Sliding Stability
solution_steps.content:
The maximum frictional resistance to sliding is:
$$F_{friction} = \mu \times P = 0.5 \times 350 \text{ kips} = 175 \text{ kips}$$

Factor of Safety against sliding:
$$FS_{sliding} = \frac{F_{friction}}{F_h} = \frac{175 \text{ kips}}{40 \text{ kips}} = 4.38$$

solution_steps.title: Evaluate Sliding Safety Factor
solution_steps.content:
For temporary construction operations, a factor of safety of 1.5 against sliding is typically acceptable.

$$FS_{sliding} = 4.38 > 1.5$$

Sliding is not a concern.

solution_steps.title: Recommendation
solution_steps.content:
Since both bearing and sliding criteria are satisfied, the 8 ft × 8 ft pad is adequate.

If the bearing pressure had exceeded $q_{all}$, the required area would be:
$$A_{req} \geq \frac{P}{q_{all}} = \frac{350,000 \text{ lbs}}{6,000 \text{ psf}} = 58.3 \text{ ft}^2$$

The square root of $58.3$ ft² is $7.64$ ft, so an 8 ft × 8 ft pad (64 ft²) would still be required, which is what was provided.

final_answer: The bearing pressure is $5,470$ psf, which is within the allowable limit of $6,000$ psf. The factor of safety against sliding is $4.38$, which is adequate.

title: Scaffolding Tube and Coupler Design Check
problem: A tube and coupler scaffold is being used for masonry work. The vertical posts (standards) are spaced at 6 ft horizontally and 8 ft longitudinally. The scaffold height is 30 ft. The posts are made of standard steel pipe with an outside diameter of 1.90 in and a wall thickness of 0.145 in (Schedule 40 pipe). The steel has $F_y = 36$ ksi. The maximum expected load per post during construction (including dead load, live load, and wind) is 8 kips. Check the adequacy of the scaffold post for compression using ASD. Assume the posts are braced laterally at mid-height by horizontal runners and bearers, providing an unbraced length of 6 ft in the weak direction and 8 ft in the strong direction. Use AISC Specification for pipe column design.
given: Scaffold post: Steel pipe, 1.90 in OD, 0.145 in wall
Height between lateral braces: $L_x = 8$ ft (longitudinal), $L_y = 6$ ft (transverse)
Maximum axial load per post: $P = 8.0$ kips (service, ASD)
required: Determine if the scaffold post is adequate for the given load using AISC ASD provisions.

solution_steps.title: Determine Slenderness Ratio
solution_steps.content:
The governing slenderness ratio is based on the larger unbraced length.

$L_x = 8$ ft = 96 in, $L_y = 6$ ft = 72 in.
Since $r$ is the same in both directions (pipe), use the larger $L$.

$$\frac{KL}{r} = \frac{1.0 \times 96}{0.622} = 154.3$$

For $L_y = 72$ in: $KL/r = 72/0.622 = 115.8$

Governing $KL/r = 154.3$

solution_steps.title: Check Maximum Slenderness Limit
solution_steps.content:
AISC Specification Section E2 states that for compression members, $KL/r \le 200$ for main members. For scaffolding, this limit is acceptable.

$154.3 < 200$, OK.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Critical Buckling Stress
solution_steps.content:
First, compute $F_e$ (elastic buckling stress) from AISC Specification Equation E3-4:
$$F_e = \frac{\pi^2 E}{(KL/r)^2}$$
$E = 29,000$ ksi

$$F_e = \frac{\pi^2 \times 29,000}{(154.3)^2} = \frac{286,000}{23,808} = 12.01 \text{ ksi}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Critical Stress $F_{cr}$
solution_steps.content:
Check limit for inelastic buckling:
$$\frac{KL}{r} \le 4.71 \sqrt{\frac{E}{F_y}}$$
$$4.71 \sqrt{\frac{29,000}{36}} = 4.71 \sqrt{805.6} = 4.71 \times 28.38 = 133.7$$

$KL/r = 154.3 > 133.7$, so use elastic buckling equation (AISC Equation E3-3):
$$F_{cr} = 0.877 F_e = 0.877 \times 12.01 = 10.53 \text{ ksi}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Nominal and Allowable Compressive Strength
solution_steps.content:
Nominal compressive strength:
$$P_n = F_{cr} \times A_g = 10.53 \times 0.801 = 8.43 \text{ kips}$$

For ASD, $\Omega = 1.67$ (Table B4-1 for compression).

Allowable strength:
$$P_{allow} = \frac{P_n}{\Omega} = \frac{8.43}{1.67} = 5.05 \text{ kips}$$

solution_steps.title: Check Against Applied Load
solution_steps.content:
Applied load $P = 8.0$ kips
Allowable $P_{allow} = 5.05$ kips

$8.0 > 5.05$, so the post is **inadequate**.

solution_steps.title: Recommendation
solution_steps.content:
The post is overstressed by about 58%. Options to fix:
1. Reduce spacing between posts to reduce tributary area and load per post.
2. Add additional lateral bracing to reduce unbraced length.
3. Use a larger pipe section.

If bracing is added at 4 ft in both directions, $KL/r = 48/0.622 = 77.2$, then:
$F_e = \pi^2 \times 29,000 / (77.2)^2 = 286,000 / 5,960 = 48.0$ ksi
$F_{cr} = 0.877 \times 48.0 = 42.1$ ksi (but limited by yielding? Check $F_y = 36$ ksi, so $F_{cr} = 36$ ksi)
$P_n = 36 \times 0.801 = 28.8$ kips
$P_{allow} = 28.8 / 1.67 = 17.2$ kips > 8.0 kips, OK.

final_answer: The scaffold post is **inadequate** for the 8-kip load. The allowable capacity is $5.05$ kips versus the applied $8.0$ kips. Additional bracing or a larger section is required.
